thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: Google Australia managing director Maile Carnegie takes aim at television
thread.title_full: Google Australia managing director Maile Carnegie takes aim at television | afr.com

author: Paul McIntyre
title: Google Australia managing director Maile Carnegie takes aim at television
text:
Maile Carnegie, managing director of Google Australia, speaking on Friday at Brandcast to more than 1000 advertisers, agencies and YouTube creators. by Paul McIntyre Google's Australian managing director Maile Carnegie put the heat on TV broadcasters on Friday, claiming Google's video platform YouTube reached more 18-54 year olds in Australia than "any single individual TV channel" and "has more than twice the reach of subscription TV".
Broadcasters and online video networks are in an escalating battle over viewers and advertising revenues, worth more than $4 billion in Australia.
Speaking to more than 1000 advertisers, agencies and YouTube creators at YouTube's slick annual Brandcast event at Sydney's Entertainment Centre, Ms Carnegie led a power line-up of local and international YouTube executives and creators making their case for TV ad budgets to swing to YouTube and for brands to get serious about co-creating content with YouTube stars who were blitzing mainstream celebrities in popularity terms among teenagers.
The timing of YouTube's pitch to marketers and the ad industry comes as TV broadcasters plan their "upfronts", presentations for 2016 in which they present programming plans and negotiate advertising market share commitments in advance from advertisers and agency groups for 2016.
Last year at the Brandcast event, Google unveiled an exclusive deal with the biggest buyer of advertising in Australia, GroupM, to take YouTube's top 5 per cent of premium ad inventory for 12 months. That contract is estimated to be worth $15 million to $30 million, and has resulted in 30 blue chip advertising clients in the GroupM portfolio using premium YouTube ads this year. The agreement expires early next year and Google is giving little away on whether it will strike a similar exclusive contract in 2016 with GroupM or a rival buying group.
Ms Carnegie ensured traditional TV broadcasters felt some pressure in front of marketers and agency buyers on Friday.
"The amount of time Australians spend on YouTube is growing at a rate that we haven't seen for years," she said. "In fact it is growing by over 60 per cent year on year. Mobile growth has been so strong that the watch time on YouTube on mobile devices alone reaches more Australians than subscription TV in total."
Clicks v watch time They are robust viewing figures but when asked by The Australian Financial Review , Google refused to break down the viewing time on YouTube that its 60 per cent Australian growth claim is based on. It again leaves the market relying on audience viewing figures published by the TV broadcaster-controlled OzTAM, which is under increasing pressure from advertisers to deliver more multi-screen and cross-platform audience measurement.
The booming tech media platforms such as Google and Facebook are less co-operative and open. When asked for details on watch time in Australia for YouTube, Google's official line was a global statement: "Everyday people watch hundreds of millions of hours on YouTube and generate billions of views."
OzTAM CEO Doug Peiffer said last week at the ASTRA TV conference that online audience and streaming numbers sounded big but when the amount of viewing time was compared to broadcast content viewing, OzTAM's best estimate was that it was 5 to 10 per cent of broadcast.
But Ms Carnegiewas upbeat about YouTube's prospects on Friday.
"Even though our reach and scale is impressive one thing you can't see in those numbers is the influence that YouTube is having on popular culture," she said. "A recent survey by Variety magazine showed that YouTube stars are now more popular than mainstream celebrities amongst US teenagers. There are now eight YouTube creators in the top 10, beating A-listers is like Taylor Swift and Bruno Mars."
Google's industry leader, Bart Jenniches, would not detail 2016 revenue or advertising market share targets for YouTube other than a rise in available premium inventory on YouTube was linked with "watch time". "Growth next year is partial to the growth of watch time and our content creators are a huge portion of that 60 per cent growth in watch time," Mr Jenniches said.
"Negotiations are ongoing. There are discussions with a variety of partners. I can't comment where the deals are at for next year but we do have quite a bit of interest. GroupM is going great with the exposure to 30-plus advertisers which have gone through Google Preferred. We have seen some great results. There are some brand lift survey results coming out I am very pleased with."
